description: Borrowed from Dutch gas, coined by chemist Jan Baptist van Helmont in Ortus Medicinae. Derived from Ancient Greek χάος (kháos, “chasm, void, empty space”); perhaps also inspired by geest (“breath, vapour, spirit”). Doublet of chaos. First attested in  1648.

nouns.description: gas (countable and uncountable, plural gases or gasses)

definitionGroups.group: (uncountable, chemistry) Matter in an intermediate state between liquid and plasma that can be contained only if it is fully surrounded by a solid (or in a bubble of liquid, or held together by gravitational pull); it can condense into a liquid, or can (rarely) become a solid directly by deposition.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A flammable gaseous hydrocarbon or hydrocarbon mixture used as a fuel, e.g. for cooking, heating, electricity generation or as a fuel in internal combustion engines in vehicles, especially natural gas.
examples: Gas-fired power stations have largely replaced coal-burning ones.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, military) Poison gas.
examples: The artillery fired gas shells into the enemy trenches.

entries.meaning: (countable, chemistry) A chemical element or compound in such a state.
examples: The atmosphere is made up of a number of different gases.

entries.meaning: (countable) A hob on a gas cooker.
examples: She turned the gas on, put the potatoes on, then lit the oven.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Methane or other waste gases trapped in one's belly as a result of the digestive process; flatus.
examples: Synonym: wind
My tummy hurts so bad – I have gas.

entries.meaning: (slang) A humorous or entertaining event or person.
(slang) Frothy or boastful talk; chatter.
(baseball) A fastball.
examples: The closer threw him nothing but gas.

entries.meaning: (medicine, colloquial) Arterial or venous blood gas.
(slang, uncountable) Marijuana, typically of high quality.

verbs.description: gas (third-person singular simple present gases or gasses, present participle gassing, simple past and past participle gassed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attack or kill with poison gas.
examples: The Nazis gassed millions of Jews during the Holocaust.
He never fully recovered after he was gassed on the Western Front.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To talk in a boastful or vapid way; chatter.
examples: "Well don't keep on gassing about it," said Digory.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To impose upon by talking boastfully.
(intransitive) To emit gas.
examples: The battery cell was gassing.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impregnate with gas.
examples: to gas lime with chlorine in the manufacture of bleaching powder

entries.meaning: (transitive) To singe, as in a gas flame, so as to remove loose fibers.
examples: to gas thread

nouns.description: gas (countable and uncountable, plural gases or gasses)

entries.meaning: (uncountable, Canada, US) Gasoline, a light derivative of petroleum used as fuel.
examples: Synonyms: (US) gasoline, (British) petrol, see also Thesaurus:petroleum

entries.meaning: (uncountable, Canada, US, by extension) Ellipsis of gas pedal.
(uncountable, cryptocurrencies) An internal virtual currency used in Ethereum to pay for certain operations, such as blockchain transactions.
examples: Coordinate term: Ether
gas fee

verbs.description: gas (third-person singular simple present gases or gasses, present participle gassing, simple past and past participle gassed)

entries.meaning: (US) To give a vehicle more fuel in order to accelerate it.
examples: The cops are coming. Gas it!
Synonyms: hit the gas, step on the gas

entries.meaning: (US) To fill (a vehicle's fuel tank) with fuel.
examples: Synonym: refuel

description: Compare the slang usage of "a gas", above.

entries.meaning: (slang) Comical, zany; fun, amusing.
examples: Mary's new boyfriend is a gas man.
It was gas when the bird flew into the classroom.
